Portland Electric

website redesign
Mobile prototype Website prototype

Project Overview

Company
Portland Electric is an electric company in Vancouver, WA. They have been on the market for more than 15 years, and never since did they update their website. Portland Electric has done a lot of big projects, and they mostly worked with the same clients for years, so they didn't need a good-functioned website a lot.

Task
Client needs a redesign of current website, adding additional features to it, make the site more user-centered and friendly.

Design goals
1. Redesign the existing website, to make it aesthetically pleasing, easy to navigate, and have all structure and content that the client provides (About page/ Contact page / Project page/ Services page)
2. Add the appointment form
3. Design a new, fresh logo for the company

Through the research and discovery phase, I find out that not all the users were ready to schedule estimate right away, some just wanted to contact and get more information, so we agreed on adding a contact form also.

Current Portland Electric website

Year
2020.

Duration
3 weeks

Tools
Figma
Maze

Discovery and research

User surveys
For this user survey, my main goal was to find out who is a target audience of PE site, which device they use when searching for the website, and also to get some feedback on what do they think about a current website, what information might be missing and what was their overall experience with PE website.

Survey participants habits:

45% - use a mobile device to search for a website

55% - use labtop

Information that participants looking the most when visiting PE website:

50% - services and definition

20% - reviews

15% - recent projects

15% - other

Most of the participants:

70% - builders/ construction company manager or director

15,8% - interior designer

14,2% - other

User interviews
In this project User interviews took a special place - I had a chance to speak with PE clients, who's been working with a company for years. My goal was to find out their experience with a website, get more details about any confusions they had, and to find out what in their opinion is the website needs to have, and why they think it's important.

Outcomes
The website has very poor navigation.
Lack of information (interviewers didn't find the description of services, projects, pictures)
All interviewers found out about PE from the third person.

Competitive analysis
According to survey results most users use the mobile app to plan their trip.
To determine the strengths and weaknesses of competitors I have done a competitive
analysis using SWOT method for the Moovit and Transit apps.

User persona

Stuart

foreman at the local builder company

Location - Portland, OR
Age - 39

Frustrations
Cannot find specific services
Will the company complete all work on time?

Core needs
Access to company availability and ability to schedule services
Find specific services
Easy collaboration with management about any updates or additional
supplies needed

Information architecture

User stories
The next step in my design process was creating User stories. They will give a more
realistic understanding of the user's goals and stay user-focused. For this model of
User stories I focused on already existing user.

User flow
In order to see how user is going to accomplish a specific task user flow
was created. I focused on 3 user stories:

Site map

Sketches and wireframes
45% of survey participants preferred to use their mobile devices at first to check the
websites. So I was creating both mobile and web versions of the product. I started
designing mobile-first.

Mobile sketches

Desktop sketches

Mobile sketches

Desktop sketches

First Usability tests
Tests were done via zoom, using the LowFI prototype. I had five participants do three simple tasks.

Tasks that were given:
1.Find if the company has services that you need.
Imagine that you need some maintenance to be done, what steps will you take?
2.Check if you can request to contact a project manager
Using this prototype show me how will you request to contact a project manager?
3. Schedule an appointment for January the 4th
How would you schedule an estimate let’s say for January the 4th?

Outcomes
Don’t change
Layout of design
Navigation was easy to use, participants have done all tasks successfully
The contact form was easy to find and use.

Content changes required
Navigation was changed by combining contact and
schedule appointment forms, navigation buttons were
added to all pages.

After change

Final Usability tests

For the second round of usability tests, the main goal was to see how users will interact
with an updated Scheduling form that I've changed after the first round of usability tests.

Main outcomes

What I learned

This project was my first experience working with a real client. It was important for me to create a product that will be
pleasing but to keep the idea and style that the company already has. I've learned that testing early is crucial in creating a
user-oriented product. Using multiple research methods helped me to know the user better and gave me a lot of
information about what exactly I needed to update at the website.
